docs.lead_paragraph: SIDNEY J. HOLBROOK manages 1,100 employees and a $90 million budget in an effort to keep the state's air and water clean, the fish and wildlife healthy. As Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, he is also responsible for boating safety, hunting, controlling forest fires and monitoring Long Island Sound. The department also oversees its own saw mill in Portland Depot to supply boards for picnic tables and a 13-acre seedling nursery in Voluntown. "Some people complain about the stringency of the environmental regulations here but I think it helps to to establish a quality of life in Connecticut that is second to none," Mr. Holbrook said. "You can feel safe breathing the air and drinking the water."

headline.main: Connecticut Q&A: Sidney J. Holbrook;Clean Air, Clean Water, Tough Rules

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Bob Herbert (column, July 15) is on the mark in calling for more disclosure on managed care. One area requiring attention is employee co-payment overcharges. Typically, employees pay 20 percent of health care costs by co-payment or co-insurance. However, health maintenance organizations and insurance companies negotiate volume discounts with providers that often are not passed on to consumers. As a result, an apparent 20 percent co-payment may represent 30, 40, 50 percent or more of total charges.

headline.main: Rationed Health Care Serves the Bottom Line;For Full Disclosure

docs.lead_paragraph: CONNECTICUT will take to the airwaves soon with a $15,000 advertising campaign to persuade baby boomers to plan for the future. The initiative comes four years after the state began encouraging its residents to plan for old age by purchasing long-term care insurance. Under the program, the state teamed up with selected private insurers that agreed to meet state standards for long-term care. But while one million people are candidates for such insurance, only 2,600 policies have been sold.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Contrary to your July 15 front-page article, health maintenance organizations represent a reprieve from the ruinous co-payments and deductibles of traditional indemnity plans. A chronically ill patient requiring expensive medical equipment in an H.M.O. goes through a certification process to insure that the proposed equipment will be safe.

headline.main: Rationed Health Care Serves the Bottom Line;H.M.O. Advantage

docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1963, when Dr. Jack Shiller was the director of public health for the town of Westport, the Sabin vaccine for polio was introduced. His goal was to get every person in the town vaccinated and so started a "Sabin on Sunday" campaign to encourage participation on peoples' day off. "What we noticed was a tremendous number of people came in," Dr. Shiller said. "They had a public health program but it was very limited, as was the case in many small towns around the state." Invited to simply come on in, people responded.

headline.main: Health Delivery at the Town Hall Level

docs.lead_paragraph: LISA JARRELL WAS SITTING ON HER CRISPLY MADE BED not long ago at the University of Virginia's hospital in Charlottesville, her tiny legs saucily crossed, daring Dr. Carlos Gomez once again to keep her alive. Jarrell was born 31 years ago with cerebral palsy, one of its cruel adjuncts being an esophagus that ended abruptly in a pouch, unconnected to her stomach. Five surgeries to fix this anomaly had riddled her frail chest with scar tissue, and over the past four years she had lost the ability to ingest and keep down food. Now for 12 hours each day, a ghastly viscous liquid seeped down a feeding tube imbedded in her abdomen to sustain her 72-pound body. Her daily list of medications, a pharmacological cornucopia addressing everything from pain to nausea to depression, filled a double-spaced sheet of paper. Late last year she tried to commit suicide, and words from her diary have continued to send up a cry to heaven for deliverance. In the thinly disguised patois of the very sick that most doctors have heard -- "I am trapped inside this body; I want to be out" -- she has cloaked her request that Gomez help her to die.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Prudential Insurance Company's Washington Street offices here make a first impression that is dramatic, but also disarmingly lighthearted. On a luxurious Italian terrazzo pavement stands a grove of treelike sculptures gaily overlaid with multicolored stone-and-glass mosaics. Farther in stand a gold-colored orb, an azure pavilion and a row of columns, similarly covered with mosaics. The lobby was not always so welcoming. "This space used to feel like a bus terminal," said Helen Zucker Seeman, the director of Prudential's art program, who was responsible for commissioning the lobby installation, "Hall of Balance," a site-specific ensemble by the sculptor Ned Smyth, in 1988. "It was a dead space. Now, the employees have their parties here."

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST fall, Kevin J. Mattakat was studying telecommunications and computer science at the University of Wisconsin. In his spare time, he tended bar and did computer work for the college. He earned about $5,700 in 1995. Today, at 30, he is making more than $45,000 a year at a subsidiary here of U S West, the regional telephone company, fixing the bugs that inevitably haunt complex computer networks.

headline.main: The New Jobs: A Growing Number Are Good Ones
